title: Introduction to Java
content:
Java is an object-oriented, statically-typed language that runs on the Java Virtual Machine (JVM). It follows the principle 'Write Once, Run Anywhere'.

Key points:
- Strong static typing
- Automatic memory management (garbage collection)
- Rich standard library and ecosystem
- Commonly used for backend, Android, enterprise systems

title: Variables & Data Types
content:
Java variables must declare a type. Primitive types include int, long, double, float, boolean, char. Objects use reference types (String, arrays, classes).

Use final to create constants. From Java 10+, var allows local type inference.

title: Operators & Expressions
content:
Java supports arithmetic, relational, logical, bitwise, and assignment operators. Note integer division truncates fractional part.

Use parentheses to enforce precedence. Use == for primitives and .equals() for object equality (often for Strings).

title: Strings & String API
content: Strings are objects (immutable). Use methods like length(), substring(), indexOf(), toUpperCase(), split(). For performance use StringBuilder for many concatenations.

title: Control Flow: if / switch / loops
content:
Control structures look similar to other languages: if/else, switch, for, while, do-while. Use enhanced for (for-each) to iterate arrays and collections.

Java 14+ has improved switch expressions.

title: Methods (Functions)
content:
Methods define behavior. Java supports method overloading (same name, different parameters). Methods belong to classes and can be static (class-level) or instance-level.

Signatures: returnType name(params).
trystarter: public static int mul(int a, int b) { return a*b; }

title: Arrays & Collections
content: Arrays are fixed-size. Collections (List, Set, Map) are dynamic and part of java.util. Use ArrayList for dynamic arrays, HashMap for key-value storage, HashSet for unique items.
trystarter:
String[] arr = {"a","b","c"};
for (String s : arr) System.out.println(s);

title: Classes & Objects
content: Classes define blueprints. Use constructors to initialize objects. Fields hold state. Use access modifiers (public, private, protected) for encapsulation.

title: Inheritance & Interfaces
content: Inheritance: class B extends A. Interfaces define contracts that classes implement (implements). Java supports single class inheritance and multiple interfaces. Use @Override to mark overridden methods.
trystarter:
class A{int x;} class B extends A{}
B b = new B();

title: Exceptions & Error Handling
content: Use try/catch/finally to handle exceptions. Java differentiates checked (must be declared/handled) and unchecked (runtime) exceptions. Use throws in method signatures for checked exceptions.
trystarter: try { String s = null; s.length(); } catch (NullPointerException e) { System.out.println("null"); }

title: File I/O & Streams
content: Java I/O supports reading/writing using java.io and java.nio. Use BufferedReader/BufferedWriter or Files utility (Java 7+) for simple tasks. Streams API (java.util.stream) helps process collections declaratively.

title: Generics
content: Generics enable type-safe code that works with different types (e.g., List<T>). Use bounded types (T extends Number) to restrict types. Generics avoid casts and ClassCastException at runtime.

title: Multithreading & Concurrency
content: Use Threads or Executors for concurrency. Synchronized, volatile, and concurrent collections (ConcurrentHashMap) help manage shared state. Prefer java.util.concurrent for higher-level primitives (Executors, Locks, Semaphores).
trystarter:
Thread t = new Thread(() -> System.out.println("Hi"));
t.start();

title: Lambda Expressions & Streams
content:
Lambdas provide concise function expressions. Streams API allows map/filter/reduce operations on collections.

Example: list.stream().filter(x->x>0).map(x->x*2).collect(...)

title: JVM, Memory & Tooling
content: Understanding the JVM is key: classloader, heap vs stack, garbage collection. Common tools: javac (compiler), java (runner), javadoc, jmap/jstack for debugging, and build tools like Maven/Gradle.
